instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens if a pump is continuously operating regardless of load?
output: If the user designates a pump that is operating continuously the pump will run regardless of whether or not there is a load. This may have the net effect of adding heat to the loop if no equipment is turned on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How does a scheduled pump operate?
output: If the pump is scheduled the schedule modifies the Rated Volumetric Flow Rate of the pump on a time basis. The default is that the pump is ON and runs according to its other operational requirements.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is the pseudo code used for in the context of pump efficiency?
output: The pseudo code is used for the calculation of the total efficiency of the pump and the actual pumping efficiency when the motor efficiency is accounted for either variable or constant volume pumps.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the formula for Total Efficiency in percentage?
output: Total Efficiency % = Rated Volume Flow Rate * Rated Pump Head / Rated Power Use

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the pseudo code for calculating Total Efficiency?
output: TotalEffic = PumpEquip(PumpNum)%NomVolFlowRate * PumpEquip(PumpNum)%NomPumpHead / PumpEquip(PumpNum)%NomPowerUse

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the formula for Calculated Pump Efficiency in percentage?
output: Calculated Pump Efficiency % = Total Efficiency % / Motor Efficiency %

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the pseudo code for calculating Pump Efficiency?
output: PumpEquip(PumpNum)%PumpEffic = TotalEffic / PumpEquip(PumpNum)%MotorEffic

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Dynamic Pump Pressure Head -> text
input: What option is available for plant/condenser loop simulations regarding pressure?
output: There is an option when performing plant/condenser loop simulations to account for dynamically changing loop pressure drop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Dynamic Pump Pressure Head -> text
input: How is the loop pressure drop calculated in the current implementation?
output: The loop pressure drop is calculated based on pressure drop data on each branch of the loop then this total pressure drop is set as the pump pressure head.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Dynamic Pump Pressure Head -> text
input: Is there a pump curve implemented in the current system?
output: There is no pump curve implemented yet so it is assumed that the pump can always handle this pressure value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Dynamic Pump Pressure Head -> text
input: What does the initial implementation of dynamic pump pressure head allow?
output: This initial implementation allows the user to enter minimal data and yet get a more dynamic output for pump power which is calculated based on current pressure drop and flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Dynamic Pump Pressure Head -> equation
input: What is the equation for pump electric power?
output: Pump Electric Power = Pump Volume Flow Rate * (Pump Head / Total Efficiency)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Dynamic Pump Pressure Head -> text
input: How is pump power calculated without pressure simulation?
output: Without the pressure simulation the pump power is based on the rated value entered with the pump object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What defines a variable speed pump in EnergyPlus?
output: A variable speed pump (object name: Pump:VariableSpeed) is defined with maximum and minimum flow rates that are the physical limits of the device.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: How does a variable speed pump operate?
output: The pump will operate and select a flow somewhere between the minimum and maximum limits.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What is the main difference between a variable volume pump and a constant volume pump?
output: The main difference between the variable volume pump and the constant volume pump is the Part Load Performance Curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> equation
input: What is the equation for Fraction of Full Load Power?
output: FractionFullLoadPower = C1 + C2*PLR + C3*PLR^2 + C4*PLR^3

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What do the coefficients C1 C2 C3 and C4 represent in the Fraction Full Load Power equation?
output: C1 C2 C3 and C4 are Coefficients 1 -- 4.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What does PLR stand for in the context of pump equations?
output: PLR stands for the Part Load Ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What assumption is made about the pump's ability to handle pressure?
output: It is assumed that the pump can always handle the pressure value as there is no pump curve implemented yet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is the purpose of the initial implementation regarding pump data entry?
output: The initial implementation allows the user to enter minimal data and get a more dynamic output for pump power.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for pump power?
output: Pump Electric Power = Pump Volume Flow Rate * (Pump Head / Total Efficiency)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How is pump power calculated without pressure simulation?
output: Without pressure simulation the pump power is based on the rated value entered with the pump object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: Where can further information about Branch objects and PlantLoop/CondenserLoop objects be found?
output: Further information can be found in the input-output reference for Branch objects PlantLoop/CondenserLoop objects and the Plant/Condenser loop section of the engineering reference.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What defines a variable speed pump?
output: A variable speed pump is defined with maximum and minimum flow rates that are the physical limits of the device.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: How does a variable speed pump operate?
output: The pump will operate and select a flow somewhere between the minimum and maximum limits to meet the flow request made by demand side components.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What is the main difference between a variable volume pump and a constant volume pump?
output: The main difference is the Part Load Performance Curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> equation
input: What is the equation for the fraction of full load power for a variable speed pump?
output: FractionFullLoadPower = C1 + C2*PLR + C3*PLR^2 + C4*PLR^3

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What do the coefficients C1 C2 C3 and C4 represent in the fraction of full load power equation?
output: C1 C2 C3 and C4 are Coefficients 1 -- 4.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What is PLR in the context of variable speed pumps?
output: PLR is the Part Load Ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Speed Pump -> text
input: What does the pseudo code for variable speed pumps illustrate?
output: The pseudo code illustrates how FracFullLoadPower modifies the NomPowerUse for total pump power and shows the ShaftPower and PumpHeattoFluid.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What new capability does the variable speed pump object have with the introduction of pressure simulations?
output: It can model a more realistic variable speed operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What are the two operation modes introduced for variable speed pumps?
output: Differential pressure control and manual control mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: How is the mode selected for variable speed pumps?
output: The mode can be selected as 'ManualControl' or 'PressureSetpointControl' in the VFD Control Type input in Pump:VariableSpeed objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What determines the current pump rotational speed in manual VFD control mode?
output: The specified schedule determines the current pump rotational speed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: How is the pump curve used in manual VFD control mode?
output: The RPM value is used to scale the pump curve which is then used with the system curve to resolve the operating point.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: How is VFD manual control mode implemented in EnergyPlus?
output: It is implemented with the use of the RPM schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the pump part load coefficient?
output: PumpEquip(PumpNum)%PartLoadCoef(1) + PumpEquip(PumpNum)%PartLoadCoef(2) * PartLoadRatio + PumpEquip(PumpNum)%PartLoadCoef(3) * PartLoadRatio^2 + PumpEquip(PumpNum)%PartLoadCoef(4) * PartLoadRatio^3

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for Power in terms of FracFullLoadPower and NomPowerUse?
output: Power = FracFullLoadPower * PumpEquip(PumpNum)%NomPowerUse

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: How is ShaftPower calculated?
output: ShaftPower = Power * PumpEquip(PumpNum)%MotorEffic

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What assumption is made about pump heat in the system?
output: It is assumed that all of the heat ends up in the fluid eventually since this is a closed loop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for PumpHeattoFluid?
output: PumpHeattoFluid = ShaftPower * (1 - PumpEquip(PumpNum)%PumpEffic)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: How is PumpHeattoFluid calculated when considering motor loss to fluid?
output: PumpHeattoFluid = ShaftPower + (Power - ShaftPower) * PumpEquip(PumpNum)%FracMotorLossToFluid

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the outlet node temperature?
output: Node(OutletNode)%Temp = Node(InletNode)%Temp + PumpHeattoFluid / (PumpMassFlowRate * LoopCp)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for PumpEquip(PumpNum)%Power?
output: PumpEquip(PumpNum)%Power = Power

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What new capability does the variable speed pump object have with the introduction of pressure simulations?
output: The variable speed pump object can now model a more realistic variable speed operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What are the two operation modes introduced for variable speed pumps?
output: Differential pressure control and manual control mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: How is the mode for variable speed pumps selected?
output: The mode can be selected as 'ManualControl' or 'PressureSetpointControl' in the VFD Control Type input in Pump:VariableSpeed objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What determines the current pump rotational speed in manual VFD control mode?
output: The specified schedule will determine the current pump rotational speed throughout the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: How is the pump curve used in manual VFD control mode?
output: The RPM value will be used to scale the pump curve which is entered by the user in non-dimensional form.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What method is used to resolve the operating point in manual control mode?
output: The successive substitution method will use the pump curve with the system curve to resolve the operating point.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: How is differential pressure based control implemented?
output: It will maintain the differential pressure within the specified range.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What is checked against the pressure set point range in differential pressure control?
output: The pressure drop corresponding to the mass flow request will be checked against the pressure set point range.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> text
input: What is the allowable mass flow rate range for differential pressure control?
output: It is explained in the figure labeled 'Allowable mass flow rate range for the Differential pressure control'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Variable Speed Pumps -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does the figure labeled 'Allowable mass flow rate range for the Differential pressure control' depict?
output: It depicts the allowable mass flow rate range for the Differential pressure control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Constant Speed Pump -> text
input: How does a constant speed pump operate?
output: The user designates a maximum flow rate and when this pump operates it will run at that capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Constant Speed Pump -> text
input: What is the main difference between constant speed pumps and variable speed pumps?
output: The fraction of full load power is always 1 for constant speed pumps.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Constant Speed Pump -> equation
input: What is the equation for VolFlowRate?
output: VolFlowRate = PumpMassFlowRate / LoopDensity

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Constant Speed Pump -> equation
input: How is PartLoadRatio calculated?
output: PartLoadRatio = VolFlowRate / PumpEquip(PumpNum)%NomVolFlowRate

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Constant Speed Pump -> equation
input: What is the value of FracFullLoadPower for constant speed pumps?
output: FracFullLoadPower = 1.0

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Constant Speed Pump -> equation
input: How is Power calculated for constant speed pumps?
output: Power = FracFullLoadPower * PumpEquip(PumpNum)%NomPowerUse

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Constant Speed Pump -> equation
input: How is ShaftPower calculated for constant speed pumps?
output: ShaftPower = Power * PumpEquip(PumpNum)%MotorEffic

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Constant Speed Pump -> text
input: What assumption is made about pump heat for constant speed pumps?
output: It is assumed that all of the heat ends up in the fluid eventually since this is a closed loop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What does differential pressure based control maintain?
output: Differential pressure based control will maintain the differential pressure within the specified range.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How is the pressure drop calculated?
output: The pressure drop corresponding to the mass flow request will be calculated using the effective pressure constant of the system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens if the pressure drop is within the user specified range?
output: If the pressure drop is within the user specified range then the mass flow rate will be checked against mass flow rates of operating points corresponding to maximum and minimum rotational speeds.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How can maximum and minimum differential pressure and rotational speeds be entered?
output: Maximum and minimum differential pressure and rotational speeds are schedule inputs and can be entered as constant schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is explained in the figure referenced?
output: The allowable mass flow rate range for the Differential pressure control is explained in the figure.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does the figure depict?
output: The figure depicts the allowable mass flow rate range for the Differential pressure control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is the operation of a constant speed pump?
output: The operation of a constant speed pump (object name: Pump:ConstantSpeed) is fairly straightforward. The user designates a maximum flow rate and when this pump operates it will run at that capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is the main difference between the constant speed pump and the variable speed pump?
output: The main difference between the constant speed pump and the variable speed pump is that the fraction of full load power is always = 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the pseudo code for calculating power in a constant speed pump?
output:
VolFlowRate = PumpMassFlowRate / LoopDensity
PartLoadRatio = VolFlowRate / PumpEquip(PumpNum)%NomVolFlowRate
FracFullLoadPower = 1.0
Power = FracFullLoadPower * PumpEquip(PumpNum)%NomPowerUse
ShaftPower = Power * PumpEquip(PumpNum)%MotorEffic

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: How is pump heat added to the fluid calculated?
output: PumpHeattoFluid = ShaftPower*(1-PumpEquip(PumpNum)%PumpEffic)\nPumpHeattoFluid = ShaftPower + (Power - ShaftPower)*PumpEquip(PumpNum)%FracMotorLossToFluid

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: How is the outlet node temperature calculated?
output: Node(OutletNode)%Temp = Node(InletNode)%Temp + PumpHeattoFluid/(PumpMassFlowRate * LoopCp)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How can the flow of a constant speed pump be overridden?
output: The constant speed pump flow can also be overridden dynamically based on a response to the plant loop pressure drop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What can the user enter for single-loop-pump simulations?
output: In single-loop-pump simulations (no branch pumps no common pipe) the user can enter a dimensionless pump curve on the Pump:ConstantSpeed object which represents the single speed pressure-flow relationship of the pump.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens if a valid pressure simulation is being performed?
output: If a valid pressure simulation is being performed a flow will be prescribed based on a resolution between system pressure characteristics and the pump pressure curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: Why is the pump flow considered unpredictable?
output: The pump flow is considered unpredictable because it will not always be a constant expected value which is basically what the constant speed pump gives you without the pressure simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What does the EnergyPlus model assume about the heat from the pump?
output: The EnergyPlus model assumes that all pressure increase caused by the pump will eventually be lost due to friction and that friction will be added as heat to the fluid.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for ShaftPower in the EnergyPlus model?
output: ShaftPower = PumpPower * PumpMotorEfficiency

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for PumpHeatToFluid in the EnergyPlus model?
output: PumpHeatToFluid = ShaftPower + (PumpPower - ShaftPower) * FracMotorLossToFluid

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens to the pressure increase caused by the pump in the EnergyPlus model?
output: The EnergyPlus model assumes that all pressure increase caused by the pump will eventually be lost due to friction and that friction will be added as heat to the fluid.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus Version 7 handle pump heat addition to the plant loop?
output: Since EnergyPlus Version 7 the pump heat is added to the plant loop interface by injecting the heat into the mixed tanks used to model loop thermal capacitance rather than at the pump's outlet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is the role of FracMotorLossToFluid in the EnergyPlus model?
output: FracMotorLossToFluid is the amount of heat generated by the pump motor that is added to the fluid loop as opposed to being lost to the environment where the pump is located. It is also a user input.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is the consequence of the shaft power in the EnergyPlus model?
output: The shaft power relates to the increase in head through the pump and since all of this head is lost through the piping network due to frictional heat it represents a heat gain by the fluid throughout the network.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens to the heat generated by the pump motor in the EnergyPlus model?
output: Some of the heat generated by the pump motor is added to the fluid being pumped and this heat is added to the loop capacitance tank(s) rather than at the pump's outlet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Constant Speed Pumps -> text
input: How can the constant speed pump flow be overridden in the EnergyPlus model?
output: The constant speed pump flow can be overridden dynamically based on a response to the plant loop pressure drop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Constant Speed Pumps -> text
input: What does the user need to enter for a single-loop-pump simulation in the EnergyPlus model?
output: The user can enter a dimensionless pump curve on the Pump:ConstantSpeed object which represents the single speed pressure-flow relationship of the pump.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Constant Speed Pumps -> text
input: What causes the pump flow to be unpredictable in the EnergyPlus model?
output: The pump flow becomes unpredictable due to a resolution between system pressure characteristics and the pump pressure curve when a valid pressure simulation is being performed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pressure-based Flow for Constant Speed Pumps -> text
input: Where can more details on the pressure-based simulation be found in the EnergyPlus documentation?
output: More details on the pressure-based simulation can be found in the Plant/Condenser loop sections of the EnergyPlus documentation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pump Heat Addition to Surrounding Zone -> text
input: What happens if a Zone is named surrounding the pump in the EnergyPlus model?
output: If a Zone is named surrounding the pump the pump becomes a source of internal heat gain to that zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pump Heat Addition to Surrounding Zone -> text
input: How is the amount of heat transmitted to the surrounding zone determined in the EnergyPlus model?
output: The amount of heat transmitted to the surrounding zone is the difference between power input and the rate of heat transferred to the fluid.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pump Heat Addition to Surrounding Zone -> text
input: What does the user input control regarding the split between thermal radiation and sensible convection in the EnergyPlus model?
output: The user can input a fraction \(f_rad\) that controls the overall split between thermal radiation and sensible convection.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: Where was loop thermal capacitance previously added?
output: Previously loop thermal capacitance was added at the outlet node of the pump.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How is the amount of heat added to the fluid calculated?
output: The amount of heat added to the fluid is calculated using two equations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for ShaftPower?
output: ShaftPower = PumpPower * PumpMotorEfficiency

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for PumpHeatToFluid?
output: PumpHeatToFluid = ShaftPower + (PumpPower - ShaftPower) * FracMotorLossToFluid

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is the pump motor efficiency defined by?
output: The pump motor efficiency is defined by the user input.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What does FracMotorLossToFluid represent?
output: FracMotorLossToFluid represents the amount of heat generated by the pump motor that is added to the fluid loop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What does the shaft power relate to?
output: The shaft power relates to the increase in head through the pump.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: Where is the heat added in EnergyPlus Version 7?
output: In EnergyPlus Version 7 the heat is added to the loop capacitance tank(s) rather than at the pump's outlet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens if a Zone surrounding the pump is named?
output: If a Zone surrounding the pump is named the pump becomes a source of internal heat gain to that zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for TotalZoneGain?
output: TotalZoneGain = PumpPower - PumpHeatToFluid

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for ConvectiveZoneGain?
output: ConvectiveZoneGain = (1 - f_rad)*TotalZoneGain

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for RadiativeZoneGain?
output: RadiativeZoneGain = f_rad*TotalZoneGain

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What do the input objects HeaderedPumps:ConstantSpeed and HeaderedPumps:VariableSpeed provide?
output: They provide models for headered pumps that consist of two or more pumps connected in parallel.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for FlowProvided?
output: FlowProvided = NumPumpsON*IndividualPumpFlowRate

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How does the simulation handle the operation of pumps?
output: The simulation starts by turning ON all pumps in the group and then turns them OFF one at a time until the flow provided is less than the flow requested.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens with constant speed headered pumps regarding the last pump?
output: In constant speed headered pumps the last pump runs at the nominal flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How is the power of the headered pump calculated?
output: The power of the headered pump is calculated using the given power equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the power of the headered pump?
output: Power = (PR_FL*N_FL + PR_PL*N_PL)*P_Nom

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for TotalZoneGain?
output: TotalZoneGain = PumpPower - PumpHeatToFluid

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for ConvectiveZoneGain?
output: ConvectiveZoneGain = \\left( 1 - f_rad \\right)*TotalZoneGain

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for RadiativeZoneGain?
output: RadiativeZoneGain = f_rad*TotalZoneGain

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What do the input objects HeaderedPumps:ConstantSpeed and HeaderedPumps:VariableSpeed provide models for?
output: The input objects HeaderedPumps:ConstantSpeed and HeaderedPumps:VariableSpeed provide models for headered pumps that consist of two or more pumps connected in parallel.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How is the headered pump simulated?
output: The headered pump is simulated as a single component and it is specified as an integer number of a specific pump.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How is the flow rate provided by the headered pump determined?
output: The flow rate provided by the headered pump is determined by the number of pumps in operation and the flow rate of the individual pump.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total flow rate of a headered pump?
output: FlowProvided = NumPumpsON*IndividualPumpFlowRate

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How does the simulation start for headered pumps?
output: The simulation starts by turning ON all pumps in the group.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens to the pumps during the simulation if the flow provided is less than the flow requested?
output: The pumps are turned OFF one at a time until the flow provided is less than the flow requested.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What happens to the last pump in the simulation to meet the remaining flow?
output: The last pump is turned back ON to meet the remaining flow (FlowDifference) requested.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How does the last pump run in constant speed headered pumps?
output: For constant speed headered pumps the last pump runs at the nominal flow rate thereby giving a final headered pump flow which is equal to or greater than the flow requested.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: How does the last pump run in variable speed headered pumps?
output: In a variable speed headered pump the last pump runs at part load so that the flow provided matches the flow requested.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the power of the headered pump?
output: Power = (PR_FL\\rm*N_\\rmFL + \\rmP\\rmR_\\rmPL\\rm*\\rmN_\\rmPL\\rm)*\\rmP_\\rmNom\\rm

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is the power consumed by the pump bank?
output: Power is the power consumed by the pump bank.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is PR_FL?
output: PR_FL is the power ratio at full load (generally equal to 1).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is N_FL?
output: N_FL is the number of pumps running at full load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is PR_PL?
output: PR_PL is the power ratio at part load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is N_PL?
output: N_PL is the number of pumps running at part load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is P_Nom?
output: P_Nom is the nominal power consumption of individual pumps.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is N_PL for a constant speed headered pump?
output: For a constant speed headered pump N_PL is zero.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What is N_PL for a variable speed headered pump?
output: For a variable speed headered pump N_PL is equal to one.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: What does the input object Pump:VariableSpeed:Condensate provide a model for?
output: The input object Pump:VariableSpeed:Condensate provides a model for steam condensate pumps.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Pumps -> text
input: Where can you find the discussion for steam loops related to condensate pumps?
output: See the discussion for steam loops reference: Condensate Pump.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What are internal heat gains in a zone?
output: Internal heat gains from lights people and equipment of various types are often significant elements in the zone thermal balance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus allow users to specify heat gains?
output: EnergyPlus allows the user to specify heat gains for several equipment types including people lights gas/electric equipment and several other types.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What comprises the total heat gain in a zone?
output: The total heat gain is comprised of convective radiant and latent gains in various proportions from these sources.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What are convective gains?
output: Convective gains are instantaneous additions of heat to the zone air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: How are radiant gains distributed in a zone?
output: Radiant gains are distributed on the surfaces of the zone where they are first absorbed and then released back into the room (with some fraction conducted through the surface) according to the surface heat balances.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: How must latent gains be handled?
output: Latent gains must be handled by ventilation or air conditioning equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: Where are recommended heat gains given?
output: Recommended heat gains are given in the ASHRAE Handbook of Fundamentals.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What do the recommendations in the ASHRAE Handbook include?
output: These recommendations include the sensible (convective plus radiative) and latent proportions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What are sensible gains from equipment primarily composed of?
output: Sensible gains from equipment are primarily radiant.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What can users specify regarding heat gains?
output: The user can specify the heat gains and proportions for any type of equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is more complicated to determine?
output: Determining the gains from lights people and baseboard heat are slightly more complicated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: What does the input object Lights provide?
output: The input object Lights provides a model for internal gains from lights.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: How must radiant gains from lights be handled?
output: Radiant gains from lights must be handled differently from other radiant gains for reasons described here (long wavelength description).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: How must the total radiant gains from lights be divided?
output: The total radiant gains from lights must be divided into visible and thermal portions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: What is the conversion of electric input for typical incandescent lights?
output: For example the total electric input to typical incandescent lights is converted to 10% visible radiation 80% thermal radiation and 10% convective gain.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: What is the conversion of electric input for typical fluorescent lights?
output: In contrast the electric input to typical fluorescent lights is converted to 20% visible radiation 20% thermal radiation and 60% convective gain (see Carrier 1965).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: Who controls the percentage splits of light gains?
output: These percentage splits are under user control with the Lights input object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: What happens when the Return Air Fraction is greater than 0 and the return air flow rate is greater than 0?
output: When the value of Return Air Fraction is greater than 0 and the return air flow rate is greater than 0 the portion of light heat will be added to the return air node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: What effect does the added heat have on the node temperature?
output: The added heat will make the node temperature rise.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: Where is the temperature difference calculated?
output: The temperature difference is calculated in the CalcZoneLeavingConditions function of the ZoneEquipmentManager module.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What is the equation for temperature rise due to added light heat gain?
output: TempRetRise = \\fracQRetAir MassFlowRA * CpAir

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What does TempRetRise represent in the equation?
output: TempRetRise is the temperature rise due to added light heat gain (C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What does QRetAir represent in the equation?
output: QRetAir is the added heat gain from return air fraction (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What does MassFlowRA represent in the equation?
output: MassFlowRA is the mass flow rate at the return node (kg/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What does CpAir represent in the equation?
output: CpAir is the specific heat (J/kg-K).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: What happens when both node names of return air and exhaust air are entered in the Lights object?
output: When both node names of return air and exhaust air are entered in the Lights object the return heat is shared by both nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: What will be the temperature of both nodes due to added return heat?
output: Both nodes will have the same temperature due to added return heat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What is the equation for temperature rise when both return and exhaust nodes are considered?
output: TempRetRise = \\fracQRetAir (MassFlowRA + MassFlowEx ) * CpAir

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What does MassFlowEx represent in the equation?
output: MassFlowEx is the mass flow rate at the exhaust node (kg/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: Is it possible to have multiple Lights objects with different return nodes?
output: Although a single Lights object allows a return node and an exhaust node it is possible to have multiple Lights objects with different return nodes and referred to the same exhaust node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> text
input: What will the exhaust node share when there are multiple return nodes?
output: The exhaust node will share return heat from different return nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What is the equation for temperature rise at the i-th return node?
output: TempRetRise_i = \\fracQRetAir_i (MassFlowRA_i + MassFlowEx ) * CpAir

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What does TempRetRise_i represent in the equation?
output: TempRetRise_i is the temperature rise at i-th return node due to added light heat gain (C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from Lights -> equation
input: What does QRetAir_i represent in the equation?
output: QRetAir_i is the added heat gain from return air fraction at i-th return node (W).

input: What does MassFlowRA_i represent in the equation?
output: MassFlowRA_i is the mass flow rate at i-th return node (kg/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is under user control with the Lights input object?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: What does the input object People provide?
output: The input object People provides a model for internal gains from occupants.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: How is heat generated in the human body?
output: Heat is generated in the human body by oxidation at a rate called the metabolic rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: How is heat dissipated from the body?
output: Heat is dissipated from the body surface and respiratory tract by a combination of radiation convection and evaporation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: What is the relative proportion of sensible and latent heat from people a function of?
output: The relative proportions of sensible (radiation plus convection) and latent (evaporation) heat from people is a complex function of the metabolic rate and the environmental conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus divide the total metabolic heat gain?
output: EnergyPlus uses a polynomial function to divide the total metabolic heat gain into sensible and latent portions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: What is the polynomial function based on?
output: That function is based on a fit to data at average adjusted metabolic rates of 350 400 450 500 750 850 1000 and 1450 Btu/h each at temperatures of 70 75 78 80 82°Fahrenheit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: What assumptions were made to give reasonable values beyond the reported temperature range?
output: Sensible gains of 0 at 96°F and sensible gains equal to the metabolic rate at 30°F were assumed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: What is the average adjusted metabolic rate?
output: Average adjusted metabolic rate (Carrier 1965b) is the metabolic rate to be applied to a mixed group of people with a typical percent composition.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is the mass flow rate at the exhaust node measured in?
output: The mass flow rate at the exhaust node is measured in kg/s.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is \(CpAir\)?
output: \(CpAir\) is the specific heat measured in J/kg-K.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is the temperature rise at the exhaust node?
output: The temperature rise at the exhaust node is a sum of all return node temperature rise.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> equation
input: What is the formula for the temperature rise at the exhaust node?
output: The formula is: \( TempRetRise = \sum_i=1 ^n\frac QRetAir_i (MassFlowRA_i + MassFlowEx ) * CpAir \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is \(TempRetRise\)?
output: \(TempRetRise\) is the temperature rise at the exhaust node due to added light heat gain measured in Celsius.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is \(QRetAir_i\)?
output: \(QRetAir_i\) is the added heat gain from return air fraction measured in Watts.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is \(MassFlowRA_i\)?
output: \(MassFlowRA_i\) is the mass flow rate at the return node measured in kg/s.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is \(MassFlowEx\)?
output: \(MassFlowEx\) is the mass flow rate at the exhaust node measured in kg/s.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Internal Gains -> text
input: What is \(n\)?
output: \(n\) is the number of Lights objects with the same exhaust node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: What is the metabolic rate for an adult female compared to an adult male?
output: Metabolic rate adult female = Metabolic rate adult male X 0.85.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text

output: Metabolic rate children = Metabolic rate adult male X 0.75.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Gain from People -> text
input: In what units was the original data?
output: The original data was in I-P (Inch-Pound) units.
